Legal_Issue: Whether the Citizenship Judge correctly applied the residency requirement under s. 5(1)(c) of the Citizenship Act
Application_Facts: Applicant had frequent absences but maintained a home and business in Canada
Decision_Outcome: Citizenship application denied due to perceived failure to meet residency requirements
Remedy_Requested: Appeal to Federal Court for reassessment
Court_Ruling: Appeal allowed; case referred back to another Citizenship Judge for reassessment
Defendant_Behavior: Citizenship Judge emphasized physical presence over overall residency ties
Grounds_for_Claim: Erroneous legal interpretation of residency requirement
Legal_Standard: Interpretation and application of s. 5(1)(c) of the Citizenship Act
Assessment_Factor: Physical presence vs. residential ties such as home and business in Canada
Procedural_Issue: Appeal from decision of Citizenship Judge
Evidence_Used: Evidence of maintained home and business in Canada despite absences
Application_Basis: Accumulation of at least 1,095 days of residence in Canada within four years preceding application
Evidence_Assessed: Residency ties including property ownership and business operations in Canada
Relief_Sought: Overturn of denial and reassessment of citizenship application
Governing_Rule: Under s. 5(1)(c), applicants must have 1,095 days of physical residence in Canada within four years prior to application
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to consider non-physical residency indicators
Harm_Assessment: Unfair denial of citizenship due to narrow interpretation of residency
Cause_Description: Applicant's citizenship application was denied based on insufficient assessment of residency
Evidence_Handling: Insufficient consideration of evidence showing ongoing residential connections
Legal_Provision_Violated: s. 5(1)(c) of the Citizenship Act (as misapplied)
Evidence_Issues: Overemphasis on physical presence; underweighting of residential ties
Residency_Compliance: Disputed compliance with 1,095-day requirement due to interpretation
Evidence_Assessment: Judge failed to assess pre-existing residency and connections to Canada
Decision_Rationale: Error in law by overemphasizing physical presence and neglecting broader residency criteria
Evidentiary_Issues: Incomplete evaluation of residency indicators beyond days present
Legal_Standard_Applied: Statutory interpretation of residency under the Citizenship Act
